header.title: Lesson 2: Herbs for Love, Power, Commanding, Compelling, Protection, Luck and Success
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Herbal Magic, Hoodoo/Voodoo

central_thesis: Specific herbs, oils, and incenses possess distinct magical properties for various purposes (love, power, protection, luck), and their effective use involves understanding their attributes, proper preparation, and precise ritual application, often aligned with planetary influences or specific folk traditions like New Orleans Voodoo/Hoodoo. The text emphasizes practical, operative magic, while providing crucial warnings about safety and the ethical considerations, particularly regarding compelling and hexing magic.

structure_content.summary: This section establishes herbs, oils, and incenses as fundamental tools in the magical practice. It highlights the importance of using correct botanical names for identification due to varied common names globally. Crucial safety warnings are given regarding the poisonous nature of many herbs and the necessity of secure storage away from children and pets. The text advises reading the entire course before attempting rituals.

An introduction to love magick, noting its rulership by the planet Venus and the general practice of performing love rituals during Venus' planetary hours. It stresses the importance of understanding the full system for successful ritual work and emphasizes ethical considerations, particularly warning against using love magic to influence married or committed individuals, deeming such actions 'Black Magick'.

This extensive section details a wide array of herbs used in love magick, including their botanical names, specific magical attributions (e.g., attraction, reconciliation, compelling, aphrodisiac, protection), and preparation methods. Herbs like Adam and Eve Root, Ambergris, Apple Blossoms, Ash Leaves, Basil, Bittersweet (with a poison warning), Black Cohosh, Black Snakeroot, Cardamom, Chrysanthemum, Civet, Cloves, Coriander, Cumin, Daisy, Damiana, Devil's Bit, Dill, Dragon’s Blood Reed, Elecampane, Eryngo, Fig, Gentian, Ginseng, Grains of Paradise, Hazel Leaves, Honeysuckle, Jasmine, Laurel, Lavender, Lemon, Licorice, Lignum Aloes, Lilac, Lily of the Valley, Lime, Lovage, Maidenhair, Marigold, Marjoram, Mint, Mistletoe, Musk, Myrtle, Orange Blossoms, Orris, Pansy, Passion Flowers, Patchouli (with significant warnings as a 'Twister Herb' for Black Magick), Pennyroyal, Periwinkle, Quassia, Rosebuds, Rosemary, Rue, Sage, Sarsaparilla, Skullcap, Senna, Snakeroot, Southernwood, Spikenard, Vervain, and Yerba Mate are discussed. Practical applications like anointing, charm bags, incenses, teas, food additives, baths, and doll magic are outlined. A specific New Orleans aphrodisiac recipe involving eggs, lemon juice, and brandy is provided.

This section summarizes that love herbs fall into categories of 'attraction' or 'problem-solving,' with varying degrees of power. It then presents several classic New Orleans recipes for love and commanding oils/incenses, including 'Lovers' Incense,' 'He's Mine,' 'Goddess of Love,' and 'Follow Me Boy,' detailing their ingredients and primary magical effects. It reiterates the role of Musk and Vanilla as commanding oils.

structure_content.chapter_title: Herbs Associated with Power, Commanding, Compelling, and Protection
structure_content.summary: This section introduces herbs for exerting power, commanding others, compelling actions, and protection. It covers herbs such as African Ginger, Agrimony, Agueweed/Bonset (with a 'STOP HEX' recipe), Althea, Angelica, Asafetida, Balm of Gilead, Bay Leaves, Benzoin, Betony, Bilberry ('Twister Herb'), Bindweed ('Twister Herb'), Bladderwrack, Bloodroot, Borage, Brimstone (with a severe warning for demonic attack), Broom Tops, Buttercup, Calamus, Caraway Seeds, Carnation, Cascara Sagrada, Cinquefoil, Clove, Comfrey Root, Curry Powder ('Twister Herb'), Dogbane ('Twister Herb'), Dragon's Blood Reed, Elder, Elm Bark, Eucalyptus, Fennel Seed ('Twister Herb'), Foxglove, Galangal (Low John), Garlic, Hawthorn, Hazel, Holy Herb, Holy Thistle, Horehound, Jalap (High John the Conqueror), Marjoram, Masterwort, Mimosa Pine, Mistletoe, Motherwort, Mullein, Oak Leaves, Palma Christi Bean, Pine Needles, Quince Seed, Rowan, St. John's Wort, Slippery Elm, Sloe Berries, Snapdragon, Storax/Styrax, Tobacco, Thyme, and Tormentil. Detailed ritual applications include charm bags, floorwashes, doll magic, and various incense formulations, with strong ethical and practical warnings, especially for 'Twister Herbs' and powerful commanding agents.

Focuses on white magickal herbs for luck and success, categorized by specific uses like money attraction, gambling luck, and removing blockages. It warns against using 'Twister Herbs' for removing blockages. Herbs discussed include Acorn, Alfalfa, Allspice (as a catalyst), Bergamot, Bistort, Buckeye, Camomile, Cherry Blossoms, Clover, Frankincense, Gum Mastic, Heal-All, Irish Moss, Job's Tears, Juniper Berries, Lemon Verbena, Lucky Hand, Mojo Wish Beans, Nutmeg, Peony, Potato, Queen of the Meadow, Sacred Bark, Sandalwood, Sea Lettuce, Seven Barks, Smartweed, Solomon’s Seal, Spearmint, Squill Root, Star Anise, Tonka Beans, Vanilla, and Yellow Dock. Methods described include charm bags, washes for gamblers, altar placement, and ingredients for prophetic dreams, money drawing powders, and success incenses.

This section acknowledges the overlapping categories and varied meanings of herbs across different traditions, stressing that practical efficacy is the 'bottom line.' It encourages practitioners to experiment to find what works best for them and to learn through consistent engagement. It illustrates how combining herbs with specific candle colors (e.g., Rosebuds with green for luck vs. red/pink for love) can direct magical intent. Several general luck and success recipes are provided, including 'Lucky Lodestone Incense/Oil,' 'Crown of Success,' 'Double Fast Luck,' and 'Good Luck Mystic,' detailing ingredients and their purposes, often with additional elements like lodestones, iron filings, and shredded dollar bills to enhance attraction.
This chapter is listed in the table of contents but no content is provided in the document snippet.

key_concepts.definition: The scientific Latin name of a plant, crucial for accurate identification of the correct species for magical use, as common names can vary regionally.
Specific astrological timeframes governed by planets, with the planetary hours of Venus explicitly recommended for performing love rituals to enhance their efficacy.
The act of applying oils to roots, candles, or other ritual items to charge them with specific magical intent, acting as a 'filter or lens to project your desires accurately'.

The use of specific herbs, oils, or fragrances to 'force or compel sexual interaction,' often cautioned as non-selective and potentially tricky in love rituals (e.g., Ambergris, Civet, Musk, Bittersweet).

Magical practices or herbs designed to remove negative influences, curses, or hexes affecting an individual or situation, often improving luck or relationships (e.g., Black Cohosh, Bay Leaves, Betony, Bloodroot, Holy Herb).

Herbs possessing dual properties, capable of both inflicting and reversing hexes or energies, requiring extreme caution and careful handling to avoid unintended negative consequences (e.g., Bilberry, Bindweed, Curry Powder, Fennel Seed, Patchouli, Dogbane).

An herb or oil that is fiery in nature and serves to activate, boost, or 'set in motion' the magical properties of other herbs within a mixture, often working on psychic planes (e.g., Cinnamon, Allspice, Capsicum).

Small bags, typically made of cloth (e.g., red flannel), filled with specific herbs, roots, or other magical items, carried on the person or placed in strategic locations to attract or repel energies for a desired magical effect.

A practice involving the creation and stuffing of dolls with specific herbs to represent and influence a target individual, used for various purposes such as stopping slander, uncovering dishonesty, or controlling infidelity.

A liquid preparation, usually an herbal tea, used to mop floors in a home or business for magical cleansing, purification, banishing negative energies, or attracting positive influences like luck or good times.

A ritual practice involving placing a natural magnet (lodestone) on an altar during money-drawing rituals and 'feeding' it with iron filings daily while visualizing money attraction, intended to make the ritual continuously effective.

Magical practices generally associated with benevolent intent, positive outcomes, and working with helpful spirits, often contrasted with Black Magick. Some herbs, like Dragon's Blood Reed and Ginseng, are explicitly identified as solely for White Magick.

Magical practices associated with negative intent, harmful outcomes, or influencing others against their will. The text strongly warns against its use, especially in personal relationships, citing karmic repercussions and danger to the practitioner.

practical_system.description: The system presented is a practical, operative form of herbal magic rooted in various folk traditions, notably New Orleans Hoodoo and European witchcraft. It operates on the principle that specific herbs, oils, and incenses possess inherent magical virtues, categorized by their primary intent (e.g., love, power, protection, luck, success). The core mechanics involve the preparation of these botanicals as oils, incenses, teas, powders, or for use in charm bags and effigies (dolls). Ritual efficacy is attained through specific applications such as anointing, burning, bathing, sprinkling, carrying, and precise timing (e.g., planetary hours). Visualization and focused intent are crucial, often combined with other magical tools like candles of specific colors and strategically chosen charm bags. The system also includes warnings for potent 'Twister Herbs' that can inflict or reverse hexes, and ethical admonitions against Black Magick.
tools: Herbs (roots, leaves, flowers, seeds, barks, berries) including specific ones like Adam and Eve Root, Dragon's Blood Reed, High John the Conqueror, Low John, Basil, Patchouli, Ginseng, Orris, etc.
Oils (love oils, power oils, essential oils, grape seed oil as a base, Unfaithful oil, Peace Oil), Ambergris, Civet, Musk.
Charm bags (red, green, blue, yellow) and flannel bags.
Candles (red/pink for love, purple for commanding/uncrossing, green for money, white for general good).
Parchment or brown paper for writing names or wishes.
Dove's Blood ink for ritual writing.
Charcoal for burning incense and herbs.
Refrigerator and plastic boxes for storing herbs to maintain potency.
Coffee filters for straining herbal preparations.
Brandy or wine as menstrua for tinctures and tonics.
Doll figures (made of specific colored fabric like brown, white, or pink) and thread (purple, blue, white, pink).
Lodestones (natural magnets) and iron filings for attraction magic.
Rock salt for cleansing, banishing, and protection.
Gold glitter or gold magnetic sand for symbolizing money/gold in luck rituals.
Piece of coral as a protective ingredient.
Shredded dollar bills to empower money-drawing formulas.
Whiskey for specific Sea Lettuce luck spells.
rituals: Anointing roots or candles with specific oils to focus and project magical desires.
Carrying herbs or roots in charm bags (e.g., red for love/protection, green for money/luck) for continuous magical influence.
Burning herbs as incenses for various effects, including attraction, banishing negative energies, mental healing, and invoking spirits.
Brewing herbal teas for internal consumption (e.g., aphrodisiacs, sexual tonics) or external use as baths and floorwashes for purification, attraction, or specific energetic charging.
Sprinkling powdered herbs or mixtures around homes, businesses, or on personal items for targeted magical effects.
Stuffing dolls with herbs and using specific thread colors for purposes such as stopping slander, uncovering dishonesty, or controlling infidelity.
Altar work involving the placement of herbs, burning candles (colored to match intent), and making offerings to spirits responsible for granting desires.
The 'Feeding your Lodestone' ritual for attracting money, involving a lodestone, iron filings, and daily visualization.

Specific recipes for complex formulas like 'Lovers' Incense', 'He's Mine' (Oil & Incense), 'Goddess of Love', 'Follow Me Boy', 'Stop Hex', 'Commanding/Compelling Oil', 'Dragon's Blood Crystal Bath', 'Fiery Wall of Protection Oil/Incense', 'Goddess of Evil' (hexing), 'Money Drawing Powder', 'Lucky Lodestone Incense/Oil', 'Crown of Success', 'Double Fast Luck', and 'Good Luck Mystic'.

relevant_quotes.text: WARNING. IF YOU HAVE CHILDREN OR PETS, MAKE SURE THAT THEY DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO YOUR RITUAL ITEMS. NOT ONLY WILL THIS HURT YOUR RITUALS BUT, MANY HERBS ETC., ARE POISONOUS AND IF TAKEN INTERNALLY CAN CAUSE DEATH!!! YOU SHOULD ALSO HAVE THE PHONE NUMBER OF THE POISON CONTROL CENTER SOMEWHERE ON OR IN YOUR BOX.

One area you MUST NEVER TOUCH is, love involving a married or committed person. While it is very hard to know if a person is really committed, you should STAY AWAY FROM INFLUENCING THESE TYPES OF RELATIONSHIPS. This is purely Black Magick. If you do cause problems in this type of relationship, I hope you get every misery you deserve! I also hope the Society does not hear about it. This path will lead you to nothing but pain and death.

Roots are more powerful than herbs or flowers and they are viewed as being similar to candles in that they generate a kind of raw energy which is focused to a specific task through the anointment process. Like oils used on candles they act as a filter or lens to project your desires accurately.

The realm of love is ruled by the planet Venus, although not all of the herbs we will discuss come under her direct power. However, when working with this kind of love ritual is it generally done during the planetary hours of Venus. More on hours and time of rituals in future lessons. You will need to totally read this course first, before starting any rituals. This will give you the full understanding of the what and how of ritual work.
By having sex with a person you are taking and giving energy. Most people are terribly Spiritually sick. To take in their energies will GREATLY HARM YOUR MAGICK.
Three of the most used and important herbs in magick are: DRAGON'S BLOOD REED, HIGH JOHN THE CONQUEROR, and LOW JOHN.

PATCHOULI: (Pogostemon cablin / Pogostemon patchouli) This is considered the most important of the love herbs and yet it is VERY, VERY TRICKY TO USE!!! Patchouli is an herb for manifestation, a materializing fragrance. In some traditions it is considered the greatest of all BLACK MAGICK HERBS!!! It is both a hexing and a materialization herb. It is another of the TWISTER HERBS!!! (...) It is a very tricky herb and unless you use it carefully and in proper balance with other control herbs to handle its power, it can really screw you up!!! You should not use this herb until you have a much greater knowledge of Magick of herbs.

Within the Haitian Voodoo tradition where black magicians sometimes create what are called “zombies” (the walking dead) there is nothing more fearful to them than salt because if a Zombie comes in contact with salt, it automatically moves outside the control of its master and becomes completely unmanageable.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant as a practical manual for contemporary occultists, particularly those interested in Hoodoo, folk magic, or eclectic herbalism. It offers a structured guide to various herbs and their magical applications, with clear, operative instructions for ritual use. Its emphasis on specific traditions (New Orleans, European witchcraft) and the inclusion of botanical names adds academic value, while the strong ethical warnings, especially regarding compelling/hexing magic and relationships, contextualize its practice within broader magical ethics. The text provides a comprehensive and accessible foundation for operative herbal magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this document is likely beginner to intermediate practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, particularly those with an interest in operative herbal magic and folk traditions. The text assumes some foundational magical knowledge (referencing 'lesson one') but provides explicit, step-by-step instructions for practical application, making it accessible to individuals ready to engage in ritual work. It is geared towards those seeking practical solutions for challenges related to love, protection, luck, and success through herbal and folk magical means.
